Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: SusChem: Fundamentals of Oxygen Electrocatalysis on Mixed-Metal Oxyhydroxides for Alkaline Membrane Electrolysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
GOALI/SusChem: Fundamentals of Oxygen Electrocatalysis on Mixed Metal Oxyhydroxides for Alkaline Membrane Electrolysis

The development of clean and sustainable energy sources is critical for the economic and environmental vitality of human civilization. Renewable energy, such as sun and wind power, is intermittent and thus expensive to integrate with traditional energy sources at the capacity needed to power the planet. Scalable, inexpensive energy storage technologies are needed. In this project, Dr. Boettcher (University of Oregon) is collaborating with Dr. Ayers at Proton OnSite (Wallingford, Connecticut) to study catalysts for converting water into hydrogen and oxygen gas using renewable electricity as the input. Hydrogen gas is a sustainable, carbon-free, renewable fuel that can be used to replace fossil fuels. It can be used in fuel cells to regenerate electricity on demand or burned like natural gas, without carbon emission. This research addresses the inefficiency of the oxygen production part of the overall reaction. The team combines fundamental studies of how the oxygen production reaction occurs, with more applied aspects of research within the industry-academic collaboration to test optimized catalysts in commercially-relevant systems. The graduate student working on the project completes an industry internship at Proton OnSite. The Proton OnSite researchers visit the University of Oregon-Eugene. The team conducts outreach activities with local middle school students. These activities engage the students in hands-on energy storage and sustainability laboratory activities on the University of Oregon campus, and introduces university freshman to scientific research through research immersion laboratory courses.

With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry, Assoc. Professor Shannon Boettcher from the University of Oregon (UO) is: (1) synthesizing new multi-cation (oxy)hydroxide oxygen-evolution catalysts to identify active-site motifs and enhance key performance criteria (intrinsic activity, electrical conductivity, and stability), (2) employing in situ and ex situ scattering, x-ray absorption, and photoelectron spectroscopy techniques to correlate local electronic structure and bonding at iron sites to measured intrinsic activities across different catalysts, and (3) applying the fundamental knowledge obtained to design catalyst architectures that are electronically and ionically wired into efficient and stable alkaline-membrane electrolyzers operating at practical current densities > 1 A cm-2. The work is carried out in collaboration with Dr. Kathy Ayers at Proton OnSite (Wallingford, CT) and her team. In support of broader-impacts goals, the project integrates research and education through programs developed by Prof. Boettcher including hands-on middle school outreach events and research-immersion laboratories for UO freshman. The industry-academic partnership is strengthened by UO PhD students completing collaborative internships at Proton OnSite, and through Proton team members visiting the UO.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of clean and sustainable energy sources is critical for the economic vitality of human civilization and environmental vitality of our planet. Renewable energy, such as that from the sun or wind, is intermittent and thus expensive to integrate with traditional energy sources at the capacity needed to power the planet. Scalable, inexpensive energy-storage technologies are needed. In this project, Dr. Boettcher (University of Oregon) collaborated with Dr. Ayers at Proton OnSite (Wallingford, Connecticut) to study catalysts for converting water into hydrogen and oxygen gas using renewable electricity as the input. Hydrogen gas is a sustainable, carbon-free, renewable fuel that can be used to replace fossil fuels. It can be used in fuel cells to regenerate electricity on demand or burned like natural gas – all without carbon dioxide emission. This research addresses the main source of inefficiency in this process, which is the oxygen production part of the overall reaction.

During the course of the project, the team combined fundamental studies of how the oxygen production reaction occurs, with more-applied research within the industry-academic collaboration to test catalysts in commercially-relevant systems. Several important fundamental discoveries were made. First, the team found that for the fastest-known catalysts – i.e. those containing iron and nickel or cobalt – the iron atoms are the ones that primarily lose electrons while the reaction is occurring. This new data is consistent with oxygen production being catalyzed by the iron sites. The team also discovered that these catalysts are highly dynamic. The structure of oxygen-evolution catalysts consisting of nickel, cobalt, and iron was found to change dramatically during the reaction at the nanometer scale. Catalysts that started out with well-defined nanoscale crystalline shapes restructured to form disordered assemblies of irregular particles. At the atomic scale, the team found that the iron sites where the catalysis occurs are also dynamic.  For example, iron species in water absorb on the surface of cobalt and nickel materials and speed up the generation of oxygen, but can also desorb and deactivate the catalyst under different conditions. This knowledge facilitates the systematic design of catalysts that are both highly active and simultaneously stable.

The team also studied catalysis of a related reaction known as water dissociation. In this reaction water molecules are pulled apart into acid and base. These catalysts are used in cell components called bipolar membranes. The team showed the catalysts enable bipolar membranes much more efficient than previously possible. This discovery can improve devices that purify water or capture carbon dioxide, in addition to electrolyzers that make hydrogen gas.

Two graduate students working on the project completed a two-month industry internship at Proton OnSite (now a subsidiary of Nel Hydrogen) where they learned to build and test high-performance water electrolyzers. The industry-academic team built commercially relevant electrolyzer devices using earth-abundant catalysts whose fundamental properties were studied. Unlike typical commercial systems that operate with membranes under acidic conditions and use expensive precious-metal catalysts, these electrolyzers operate under basic conditions. The team discovered that the factors controlling activity and durability for the catalysts in the small cells used in academic laboratories are different from those that control these factors in systems relevant for commercialization. This discovery opens up new areas of research in understanding these differences and how to optimize catalysts for commercial applications based on fundamental scientific principles.

The team also conducted an array of activities designed to recruit, inspire and educate the next generation of scientists. The team conducted outreach activities with local underserved middle-school students. These activities engage diverse students in hands-on energy-storage and sustainability laboratory activities on the University of Oregon campus and work to develop an “I can see myself as a scientist” self-image. Graduate students supported by this grant also developed and implemented research-immersion laboratory courses for first-year chemistry students at the University of Oregon. Participants in these courses earned general chemistry laboratory credit by working in teams of 3-4 on real research questions associated with this National Science Foundation grant. Some of those students went on to join the graduate students as undergraduate research assistants after the course was completed. In addition to the students in the research course, five undergraduates contributed to the research and six of the resulting publications have undergraduate co-authors. This award has been particularly important for the careers women scientists – the two primary graduate students supported on this award were women and both graduated with a PhD and secured high-level research positions in industry and academia.


Last Modified: 09/04/2020
Modified by: Shannon W Boettcher
